hadiths.text: "When time draws near, the dreams of a believer will hardly ever  fail  to come true, and the most truthful of them in dreams will be the truest in speech among them. The dream of a Muslim is a portion among the forty-six portions of Prophet-hood. And dreams are of three types: The righteous dream which is good news from Allah, dreams in which the Shaithan frightens someone, and dreams about something that has happened to the man himself. So when one of you sees what he dislikes, then he should get up and spit, and not tell any of the people- he said:- and I like the fetters in a dream while I dislike the iron  collar." And the interpretation of fetters is being firm in the religion".
hadiths.narratedBy: Abu Hurairah narrated that the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said:

hadiths.text: "The dreams of the believer are a portion of the forty-six portions of Prophet-hood".
hadiths.narratedBy: 'Ubadah bin As-Samit narrated that the Prophet (s.a.w) said:

hadiths.text:
"The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said:
'Indeed Messenger-ship and Prophethood have been terminated, so there shall be no Messenger after me, nor a Prophet.'" He(Anas) said:"The people  were concerned about that, so he (s.a.w) said: 'But there will be Mubash-shirat.' So they said: 'O Messenger of Allah! What is  Mubash-shirat?' He said: 'The Muslim's dreams, for it is a portion of the portions of Prophethood.'"
hadiths.narratedBy: Anas bin Malik narrated:

hadiths.text: I asked Abu Ad-Darda about the saying of Allah, Most High: 'For them are glad tidings in the life of the present world' so he said: 'No one other than you asked me about it, except for one man, since I asked the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w), he said: 'No one other than you has asked me about it since it was revealed: This Ayah refers to the righteous dreams which the Muslim sees or which are seen about him."
hadiths.narratedBy: 'Ata' bin Yasar narrated from a man among the inhabitants of Egypt who said:

hadiths.text: "The most truthful of dreams are in the last hours of the night."
hadiths.narratedBy: 'Abu Sa'eed narrated that the Prophet (s.a.w) said:

hadiths.text: "  the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) about For them are glad tidings in the life of the present world. He said: 'This refers to the righteous dreams which the Muslim sees or which are seen about him.'"
hadiths.narratedBy: It is narrated from 'Ubadah bin As-Samit, who said:

hadiths.text: "Whoever saw me  (in a dream) while sleeping then he has indeed seen me. For indeed the Shaitan can not resemble me."
hadiths.narratedBy: 'Abdullah narrated that the Prophet (s.a.w) said:

hadiths.text: "Dreams are from Allah and Hulum are from Shaitan. So when one of you sees something that bothers him, then let him spit on his left three times, and let him seek refuge in Allah from its evil. Then it will not harm him."
hadiths.narratedBy: 'Abu Qatadah narrated that the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said:

hadiths.text:
" The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w)  said:
" The believer's dreams are a portion of the forty portions of Prophet-hood. And it is (as if it is) on the leg of a bird, as long as it is not spoken of. But when it is spoken of it drops." I think he said: " And it should not be discussed except with an intelligent one or a beloved one."
hadiths.narratedBy: Waki' bin 'Udus narrated that Abu Razin Al-'Uqaili said:

hadiths.text: " The Muslim's dreams are a portion of the forty-six portions of Prophet-hood. And it is (as if it is) on the leg of a bird, as long as it is not spoken of. But when it is spoken of it falls."
hadiths.narratedBy: Waki' bin 'Udus narrated from  Abu Razin that the Prophet (s.a.w)  said:

hadiths.text: "Dreams are of three types: The true dream, dreams about something that has happened to the man himself, and dreams in which the Shaitan frightens someone. So whoever sees what he dislikes, then he should get up and perform Salah." And he would say: "I like fetters and I dislike the iron collar." And he would say: " Whoever has seen me (in a dream) then it is I , for indeed Shaitan is not able to resemble me." And he would say: "The dream is not to be narrated except to a knowledgeable person or a sincere advisor."
hadiths.narratedBy: Abu Hurarirah narrated that the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w)  said:

hadiths.text:
" From the Prophet(s.a.w), who said:
"Whoever lies about his dream, he will be required to knot barely kernels on the Day of Judgement."
hadiths.narratedBy: Abu 'Abdur-Rahman(As-Sulami) narrated from 'Ali and I think he said:

hadiths.text:
This narration is Hasan.]
There are narration on this topic from Ibn 'Abbas, Abu Hurairah, Abu Shuraih and Wathilah bin Al-Asqa'.
hadiths.narratedBy: (another chain) from Abu 'Abdur-Rahman As-Sulami who narrated from    'Ali from  the Prophet with similar narrations. [He said:

hadiths.text: "Whoever lies about having a dream, he will be required to knot two barely kernels together on the Day Of  Judgment., and he will never be able to knot them together."
hadiths.narratedBy: Ibn 'Abbas  narrated that the Prophet (s.a.w) said:

hadiths.text: "While I was sleeping ,  I was brought a cup of  milk and I drank from it. Then I gave what I had left to 'Umar bin Al-Khattab." They said; "How did you interpret it O Messenger of Allah?" He said: "Knowledge."
hadiths.narratedBy: Ibn 'Umar  narrated that the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said:

hadiths.text: "While I was sleeping I saw people presented before me, and that they were wearing shirts. Some of them (the shirts) reaching their breasts, and some of them reaching below that." He said: "Then 'Umar was presented before me and he was wearing  a shirt that was dragging." They said: "How did you interpret that O Messenger of Allah?" He said: "The religion."
hadiths.narratedBy: Abu Umamah bin Sahl bin Hunaif narrated from some of the companions of the Prophet (s.a.w) that the Prophet (s.a.w) said:

hadiths.text: similar in meaning (to no. 2285).
hadiths.narratedBy: Abu Umamah bin Sahl bin Hunaif narrated from Abu Sa'eed al-Khudri that the Prophet (s.a.w) said:

hadiths.text:
"One day the Prophet (s.a.w) said:
"'Who among you had a dream?' A man said: "I did. I saw as if a scale had descended from the Heavens in which you and Abu Bakr were weighed So you outweighed Abu Bakr. Abu Bkar and 'Umar were weighed, and Abu Bakr outweighed ('Umar). 'Umar and 'Uthman were  weighed and 'Umar outweighed ('Uthman). Then the scale was raised up.' Then I saw dislike in the the face of Messenger of Allah (s.a.w)."
hadiths.narratedBy: Abu Bakrah  narrated:

hadiths.text:
"The Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) was asked about Waraqah. Khadijah said to him:
'He believed in you, but he died before your advent.' So the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said: 'I saw him in a dream, and upon him were white garments. If he were among the inhabitants of the Fire then he would have been  wearing other than that.'"
hadiths.narratedBy: 'Aishah said:

hadiths.text: "I saw that the people had gathered, so Abu Bakr drew a bucket or two buckets- in  him was some weakness- and Allah forgive him. Then 'Umar stood to draw and the bucket turned into a very large one, and I have never seen a strong man toiling so hard until it was as if the people had gathered at a (camel) watering hole."
hadiths.narratedBy: Salim bin 'Abdullah narrated from 'Abdullah bin 'Umar about the dream of the Prophet (s.a.w) and Abu Bakr and 'Umar, so he said:

hadiths.text: "I saw a black woman with unkempt hair going out of Al-Madinah, until she stood in Mabaya'ah, and it is Al-Juhfah. So I interpreted that to be an epidemic in Al-Madinah that would spread to Al-Juhfah."
hadiths.narratedBy: Salim bin 'Abdullah narrated from his father about the dream of the Prophet (s.a.w) who said:

hadiths.text: "In the end of time, the dreams of a believer will hardly ever fail to come true, and the most truthful of them in dreams will be the truest in speech among them. And dreams are three types: The good dreams wihich is glad  tidings from Allah, dreams about something that has happened to the man himself, and dreams in which the Shaitan  frightens someone. So when one of  you sees what he dislikes, then he should get  up and perform Salat." Abu Hurairah said: "I like fetters and dislikes, the iron collar. And fetters refers to being firm in the religion." He said: "The Prophet (s. a. w)  said: 'Dreams are a portion among the forty_six  portions of  Prophethood."
hadiths.narratedBy: Abu Hurrairah narrated that the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) said:

hadiths.text: "I had a dream while sleeping as if there were two gold bracelets in my hands  which bothered me very much. So it was reveled to me to blow them off. I blew them  off and they flew away. I interpreted thwm to be two liars who would appear after me. One of them caled Masalamah of Yamamah, and (the other) Al-'ansi of San'a'." (sahih)
hadiths.narratedBy: Ibn 'abbas narrated fro Abu Hurairah that the Messengr of Allah (s.a.w) said:

hadiths.text: "I had a dream of a cloud with shade dripping butter and honey. I saw the people scooping it up with their hands, some taking much and some taking little. I saw a rope extending from the  sky to the earth. Then I saw you O Messenger of Allah ! You took hold of it and went up, then a man took hold of it after you do so, then a man took hold of it after him to do so. Then a man took hold of it and it was severed, and then  connected for him, and he did so (i.e. , went up)." Abu Bakr said: "May my father and mother be ransomed for you O Messenger of Allah! Allow me to interpret it." He said: "Interpret it." so he said: "As for the cloud with its shade, it is Islam. As for what the butter and honey that dropped from it, this is the Quran and its delicateness and sweetness. It means some of them gathered much of the Quran and some of them a little. As for the rope extending from the sky to the earth, it is the truth which you are upon, you clug to it and Allah exalted you. Then another man will take hold of it after you and ascend on it, then after him, another man will take hold of it and ascend on it. Then another  will take hold of it but it will break, then be connected  so he will ascend on it. Inform me O Messenger of Allah! Am I correct or am I mistaken?" The Prophet (s.a.w) said: "You are correct in some of it and mistaken in some of it." He (i.e., Abu Bakr) said: "I swear to you by my father and my mother O Messenger of Allah! Inform me in what I was mistaken?" The Prophet(s.a.w) said: "Do not swear."
hadiths.narratedBy: Abu Hurairah narrated that a man came to the Prophet (s.a.w) and said:

hadiths.text: "When the Messenger of Allah (s.a.w) had led us in Subh(Fajr prayer), he turned to face the people and said: 'Did any of you have a dream during the night?'"  This is how Bundar reported this Hadith, with its brevity, from Wahib bin Jarir.
